trans-unit.source: Provides data for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.TextBoxBase.TextChanged"></xref> event.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventArgs"></xref> class, using the specified event ID and undo action.
The event [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_id](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-id-md.md)].
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventArgs.UndoAction*> caused by the text change.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventArgs"></xref> class, using the specified event ID, undo action, and text changes.
TextChangedEventArgs is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The event [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_id](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-id-md.md)].
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventArgs.UndoAction*> caused by the text change.
The changes that occurred during this event.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventArgs.Changes*>.
Gets a collection of objects that contains information about the changes that occurred.
There is one <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object for each consecutive change to the control.

More than one consecutive change can occur during one occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.TextBoxBase.TextChanged> event when the change entails changing the structure of the underlying document.

For example, suppose that a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.RichTextBox> contains the string `"This is some text."` The structure of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.RichTextBox.Document%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is `<Paragraph><Run>This is some text.</Run></Paragraph>`.

If the user bolds the words `"is some"`, the structure of the underlying <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> changes to `<Paragraph><Run>This </Run><Run FontWeight="Bold">is some</Run><Run> text.</Run></Paragraph>`.
There are actually four changes that took place as a result of the user's action: 1.
The `<Run>` symbol is removed and re-added before the word `This`.
The symbols `</Run><Run>` are added after the word `This`.
The symbols `</Run><Run>` are added after the word `some`.
The `</Run>` symbol is removed and re-added after the word `Text`.
In general, the following will always be true: - The changes that occur result in the document being in a valid state.
- The collection is ordered consecutively, related to where the change occurred in the control.

For example, a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object that represents a change at position 2 is before a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object that represents a change at position 10.
- Two <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> objects do not represent an overlapping area.

The value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.Offset%2A> plus the value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.AddedLength%2A> of one <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object is always less than or equal to the value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.Offset%2A> of the next <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object in the collection.

Likewise, the value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.Offset%2A> plus the value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.RemovedLength%2A> of one <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object is always less than or equal to the value of <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.Offset%2A> of the next <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object in the collection.
- The collection reflects whatever changes occurred, even if there seems to be no net change.
In the preceding example, neither the first or fourth change results in a net change, because each simply removed and re-added the `<Run>` and `</Run>` symbols, respectively.
But the symbols were actually removed and added, so they are included in the collection.
If the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.TextBoxBase.TextChanged> event occurs as a result of a property change, Changes is an empty collection.

In the preceding example, if the user bolds the entire string, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextElement.FontWeight%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Run> is set to <xref:System.Windows.FontWeights.Bold%2A>, but nothing is added or removed from the document, so Changes is empty.
Changes is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
A collection of objects that contains information about the changes that occurred.

Performs the proper type casting to call the type-safe <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TextChangedEventHandler"></xref> delegate for the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.TextBoxBase.TextChanged"></xref> event.
The handler to invoke.
The current object along the event's route.
Gets how the undo stack is caused or affected by this text change
The <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.UndoAction"></xref> appropriate for this text change.
